article:
The distinguished surname 'Story' (and its variant spelling Storey) originates
from the Old Norse personal epithet âStÃ³riâ, a derivative of âStorrâ which means
âlargeâ or âbigâ. Even though it has been established that the root of the name
is âStorrâ, R.E.K. Rigbeye, in his book The Storeyâs of Old claims that the
suffix âey[e]â, in the variant of Storey, is equivalent to the Icelandic âigâ
and signifies âwaterâ. According to him, âStorrâ also denotes large in the sense
of vast and rough. Rigbeyeâs assumption therefore, is that âStoreyâ means
"dweller by large and rough water". This may be explained by the Norse affility
to sea exploration, or the fact that the first Storys settled near the Lake
District, and so the name might refer to the habitation which they chose. The
earliest Norse settlement of which the first Storys would have been a part, took
place in the 9th century north of Carlisle near the Solway Firth. This area then
known as Strathclyde, was situated in the northwestern part of England, along
the Scottish border. The earliest Storys would have settled on the English side
of the border, most likely in the plains along the river Eden. The English or
Anglo-Saxon population, among whom the Norse settled, spoke a similar language
but pronounced many words in a different way. So, âStorrâ among the Norse would
have been enunciated as âStyrâ in English.

One of the earliest mentions of the name is âStyr (Saxon for Stor) who gave the
manor of Durham with other places to the Abbot of Lindisfarne in the year 999
A.D.â (Symeonis Dunelmensis, vol I, pp. 150â154.) The forenames Stori and Estori
(without surname) are recorded in the Domesday Book of 1066 (Derbyshire), a
survey of England conducted for William the Conqueror. Those who bore such names
were of Norse blood. (The Scandinavian "Stor", "Stori" and "Storius" occur prior
to Domesday Survey.) Afterwards, the name can be traced down in the Northern
English counties, particularly Yorkshire. The surname Story is first found in
the 1248 Feet of Fines or Fine Court Rolls of Essex, and shows to be that of a
certain Alexander (Essex Arch. Soc. 4 Vols, 1899 - 1964). A âReginaldus filius
[son of] Storyâ is mentioned in the Assize Court Rolls of Yorkshire (1219) (York
Arch. Soc. 44, 100, 1911, 1939; Seldon Soc. 56, 1937). The surname from this
source is first recorded circa 1250. Other spellings of the name are Stori
(William, 1281), with Storre and Staury, the 1379 Poll Tax Returns Records of
Yorkshire. More examples of various spellings include: Alan le Storeys 1272,
Ricus Stury or Storey 1350, Johannes Storey, Rector of Richmondshire 1429, Dr
Edward Storey or Story 1464, John Story 1476, Nicholas Storie of Liddesdale
1590, Thomas Story of Wall 1666.

During the reign of Edward I (1272 to 1307), the kingdoms of England and
Scotland went to war, and for the next 300 years, the Storys found themselves
entangled in the Border wars between the two kingdoms. A coat of arms was
bestowed on the family by (or during the reign of) Richard II of England
(reigned 1377-1399). It shows a shield with a blazon of argent (silver)
thereupon a lion rampant double queued (two-tailed) purple charged on its
shoulder with a so-called âcross pattÃ©eâ in argent (silver), the crest
consisting of the face of a leopard out of a ducal crown (coronet). A bloody
feud between the Stor(e)ys and Grahams in the 16th century, forced many family
members to migrate eastward from the region surrounding the City of Carlisle, to
Northumberland in the east.

The name may refer to many people:

* Alfred Thomas Story (1842â1934), English journalist, poet and author of
  numerous books
* Bonnie Story, American Emmy Award-winning choreographer
* Carl Story (1916â1995), influential bluegrass musician and leader of the
  "Rambling Mountaineers"
* Christopher Story (1938â2010), a British writer, publisher and
  government adviser
* Edward Story (15th-centuryâ1503), English Bishop
* George Warter Story (1664â1721), English clergyman
* Henri Story (1897â1944), Belgian businessman and liberal politician in Ghent
* Jack Trevor Story (1917â1991), British novelist
* Jamie Story
* Jeff Story born 1962, Shelton, Wa, Website http://www.jeffstory.org
* John Story (1504â1571), English martyr
* John Douglas Story (1869â1966), Australian public servant
* Joseph Story (1779â1845), American jurist
* Karl Story (born 1967), American comic book artist
* Laura Story, singer-songwriter from Spartanburg, South Carolina
* Liz Story (born 1956), American pianist
* Luther H. Story (1931â1950), soldier and Medal of Honor recipient in the
  United States Army during the Korean War
* Marguerite Story (1922â2009), Speaker of the Legislative Assembly of the Cook
  Islands from 1965 to 1979
* Nat Story (1904â1968), American jazz trombonist
* Nelson Story (1838â1926), pioneer Montana entrepreneur, cattle rancher, miner
  and vigilante
* Owen Story (born 1987), English professional footballer
* Ralph Story (1920â2006), American radio and television personality
* Richard W. Story (born 1953), United States federal judge
* Rick Story (born 1984), American mixed martial artist
* Riz Story (born 1971), American composer
* Robert Story (born 1952), Republican Party member of the Montana Senate
* Robert Herbert Story (1835â1907), Scottish Divine and Principal of the
  University of Glasgow
* Samuel Story (1752â1811), Dutch naval commander
* Story Landis, American neurobiologist and director of the National Institute
  of Neurological Disorders and Stroke
* Thomas Story (1670â1742), English Quaker convert and friend of William Penn
* Thomas Waldo Story (1855â1915), English/American sculptor
* Tim Story (film director)
* Vernon Story (1922â2007), American jazz tenor saxophonist
* Walter Scott Story (1879â1955), American author
* William Wetmore Story (1819â1895), American sculptor, son of Joseph
  Story (above)
* Anne Story(1741-1817) Revolutionary war patriot
